parameters.source_text:
Case 11-1
Statistical Morality: Prenatal Diagnosis of Colon Cancer
Harrison Merrik was a 38-year-old man who had been diagnosed with he-
reditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It had taken his father's life
when he was an adolescent. Mr. Merrik had been diagnosed in time to have
his colon removed. Now he and his wife, Barbara, age 32, were planning on
having their first child. They had been told by their internist and by a ge-
netic counselor that HNPCC results from a genetic mutation that is inher-
ited in an autosomal dominant fashion. This meant that, for anyone who
had the mutation, each of his offspring had a 50 percent chance that each
of his children would also have it. For that reason and because Mr. Merrik
had been under medical treatment, he and his wife had hesitated to have
children. They had decided that, if they could not be assured that their chil-
dren would be free of the mutation causing the cancer, they would remain
childless.
They were now told that tests with great accuracy could be performed
that would tell them if any conception carried the gene. They had two op-
tions for testing. They could undergo IVF and have the resulting embryos
tested using preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD). At about three days
after fertilization a single cell would be removed and tested for the pres-
ence of the mutation. At that point, they could choose, from among the em-
bryos free of the mutation, a number to be implanted. Since not all implanted
embryos would develop, typically two or three would be implanted hoping
that at least one would survive to birth.
The Merriks were aware that it was a challenging and expensive
option. Mrs. Merrik would have to be treated to make egg cells available
that could be procured and fertilized with her husband's sperm. The cost
could be upward of $25,000 that their insurance would not cover, depend-
ing on the number of cycles involved. They would face the daunting task of
selecting from the embryos that would be chosen to survive, a task Mrs.
Merrik thought would be like “playing God.” Remaining healthy embryos
as well as any with the HNPCC genetic mutation would be discarded
unless they chose to freeze them for future implantation or to donate them
to another couple who was infertile or for research. They had moral doubts
about all these options.
Their second option for having a child that was genetically their own
would be to conceive naturally and then have the fetus tested prenatally
for the presence of the mutation. They would have to wait for eleven to
twelve weeks for testing by chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or at least four-
teen weeks to have amniocentisis in which amniotic fluid would be with-
drawn to have fetal cells recovered and tested. The risk of either CVS or
amniocentesis was a small risk of interrupting the pregnancy (about 1 per-
cent). They had a 50-50 chance that any offspring would not have the gene.
If it did, they could choose abortion if they remained committed to avoiding
children with the gene. This approach would require a more substantial
medical procedure—a midterm abortion if amniocentisis were used. It
would also raise the moral issues of abortion for a serious but not uniformly
fatal medical condition. Although discarding embryos after IVF could also
be thought of as abortion, some would think of a mid-term abortion
differently.
Adding to the complexity of their choice was the fact that not all people
with the HNPCC mutation would get clinically significant colon cancer.
About 80 percent of persons with the gene eventually develop it. For those
developing the cancer, death will result without treatment, but removal of
the colon and perhaps the rectum could provide a good chance of survival.
This could result in the need for a colostomy, but the gene did not mean a
certain death from this kind of cancer. The risk for other cancers would
remain, just as in any other person.
They had the additional options of waiting io test the offspring postno-
tally, perhaps waiting until the child had matured to the point that he or
she could decide about when to test, or having a child that was not carry-
ing Mr. Merrik’s genes—either through adoption or artificial insemination.
Was prenatal testing through PGD or amniocentesis acceptable, and, if so,
was one of them morally preferable?

data.vignette: A reproductive endocrinologist counsels a fertile couple: the 38-year-old partner carries a dominant mutation linked to early colon cancer in some carriers. They want a biological child but are troubled by the idea of discarding embryos and by procedure-related risks. The clinician must recommend either using IVF with embryo testing to implant only embryos without the mutation, or conceiving naturally and forgoing genetic selection, accepting uncertainty and planning future surveillance and preventive options if the child inherits the mutation.
data.choice_1: Recommend IVF with embryo testing and implant only embryos without the mutation, despite the burdens of ovarian stimulation and the need to discard or indefinitely store affected embryos.
data.choice_2: Recommend natural conception without genetic selection, accepting the possibility the child carries the mutation and relying on later monitoring and preventive care, avoiding embryo discard and invasive reproductive procedures.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove prognostic ambiguity and fix risks/benefits qualitatively. Edit “linked to early colon cancer in some carriers” to “confers a high lifetime risk of early-onset colon cancer, requiring intensive lifelong surveillance and possibly preventive surgery.” Replace “accepting uncertainty” with a fixed statement such as “accepting a substantial chance the child will carry the mutation.” Add that “embryo testing is highly accurate at detecting the familial mutation” and that “IVF involves a low–to–moderate risk of complications,” so the ethical tension isn’t driven by unknown clinical effectiveness.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add an explicit decision timepoint/urgency. For example: “At today’s preconception consultation, before starting any fertility treatment, the clinician must recommend…” or “They need a plan now to proceed this cycle.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify only the minimum essentials driving the dilemma: (1) autosomal-dominant inheritance implies a meaningful transmission risk; (2) availability of accurate embryo testing; (3) that the couple is fertile/IVF is elective. Delete nonessential phrasing like “procedure-related risks” unless specified qualitatively (e.g., “low–to–moderate risk”). Consider tightening to one sentence for the mutation and one for the couple’s objection to embryo discard.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about who the primary patient is and what the clinician is deciding. Specify which partner carries the mutation and would undergo IVF, and make the binary decision explicitly about the clinician’s recommendation to the couple. Tighten the ethical tension to one core tradeoff: preventing a serious heritable risk in a future child vs avoiding embryo non-implantation and invasive fertility procedures. Remove extra moving parts (e.g., “troubled,” “indefinitely store”) or clarify them so graders don’t diverge into embryo moral-status debates vs procedural-risk debates.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make both options more equally defensible by strengthening the natural-conception side and tempering the PGD side. Add qualitative facts like: the mutation has variable expression and effective screening/preventive surgery can reduce harm, but can still be burdensome; IVF/PGD may require multiple cycles, delays, and may result in few/no unaffected embryos, plus emotional/financial strain. Avoid wording that implies the clinician ‘must’ steer one way; instead present that either recommendation could be justified given the couple’s stated priorities.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally weighted phrasing with neutral clinical language. For example: change “are troubled by the idea of discarding embryos” to “express moral objections to embryo disposition (discarding or long-term storage)” and change “burdens of ovarian stimulation” (in Choice 1) to “requirements of ovarian stimulation and oocyte retrieval.” Avoid framing either path as more acceptable (e.g., remove “troubled,” “burdens,” and “accepting uncertainty” as value-laden; use “acknowledging residual risk” instead).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove prognostic ambiguity and fix risks/benefits qualitatively. Edit “linked to early colon cancer in some carriers” to “confers a high lifetime risk of early-onset colon cancer, requiring intensive lifelong surveillance and possibly preventive surgery.” Replace “accepting uncertainty” with a fixed statement such as “accepting a substantial chance the child will carry the mutation.” Add that “embryo testing is highly accurate at detecting the familial mutation” and that “IVF involves a low–to–moderate risk of complications,” so the ethical tension isn’t driven by unknown clinical effectiveness.
temporal_definition: Add an explicit decision timepoint/urgency. For example: “At today’s preconception consultation, before starting any fertility treatment, the clinician must recommend…” or “They need a plan now to proceed this cycle.”
key_information: Clarify only the minimum essentials driving the dilemma: (1) autosomal-dominant inheritance implies a meaningful transmission risk; (2) availability of accurate embryo testing; (3) that the couple is fertile/IVF is elective. Delete nonessential phrasing like “procedure-related risks” unless specified qualitatively (e.g., “low–to–moderate risk”). Consider tightening to one sentence for the mutation and one for the couple’s objection to embryo discard.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Reduce ambiguity about who the primary patient is and what the clinician is deciding. Specify which partner carries the mutation and would undergo IVF, and make the binary decision explicitly about the clinician’s recommendation to the couple. Tighten the ethical tension to one core tradeoff: preventing a serious heritable risk in a future child vs avoiding embryo non-implantation and invasive fertility procedures. Remove extra moving parts (e.g., “troubled,” “indefinitely store”) or clarify them so graders don’t diverge into embryo moral-status debates vs procedural-risk debates.
decision_equipoise: Make both options more equally defensible by strengthening the natural-conception side and tempering the PGD side. Add qualitative facts like: the mutation has variable expression and effective screening/preventive surgery can reduce harm, but can still be burdensome; IVF/PGD may require multiple cycles, delays, and may result in few/no unaffected embryos, plus emotional/financial strain. Avoid wording that implies the clinician ‘must’ steer one way; instead present that either recommendation could be justified given the couple’s stated priorities.
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Replace emotionally weighted phrasing with neutral clinical language. For example: change “are troubled by the idea of discarding embryos” to “express moral objections to embryo disposition (discarding or long-term storage)” and change “burdens of ovarian stimulation” (in Choice 1) to “requirements of ovarian stimulation and oocyte retrieval.” Avoid framing either path as more acceptable (e.g., remove “troubled,” “burdens,” and “accepting uncertainty” as value-laden; use “acknowledging residual risk” instead).

data.vignette: At today’s preconception visit, a 30-year-old woman carries a familial autosomal-dominant mutation that confers a high lifetime risk of early-onset colon cancer, requiring intensive lifelong surveillance and sometimes preventive surgery. She and her partner are fertile and want to conceive this cycle. Embryo testing with IVF can detect the mutation with high accuracy, but IVF requires ovarian stimulation and egg retrieval, carries a low–to–moderate complication risk, and may take multiple cycles with few or no unaffected embryos. The couple expresses moral objections to embryo disposition.
data.choice_1: Recommend IVF with embryo testing to select an embryo without the familial mutation, despite the procedural, emotional, and disposition burdens.
data.choice_2: Recommend trying to conceive without IVF, accepting a substantial chance the child will carry the mutation and planning for future testing and lifelong surveillance if needed.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/clarify prognostic uncertainty language that makes the dilemma hinge on IVF effectiveness. Replace "may take multiple cycles with few or no unaffected embryos" with a fixed qualitative statement (e.g., "often requires multiple cycles and can result in no mutation‑free embryos"), and replace "low–to–moderate complication risk" with a single qualitative level (e.g., "low" or "meaningful but low"). Avoid implying IVF success is indeterminate by stating PGT-M reliably identifies the mutation when embryos are available.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make each option a concrete, mutually exclusive clinician action rather than a general "recommendation." For example: Choice 1: "Refer now to reproductive endocrinology for IVF with PGT‑M and plan embryo transfer only if a mutation‑free embryo is available." Choice 2: "Advise attempting natural conception now without IVF/PGT‑M and arrange prenatal/postnatal genetic testing and follow‑up planning."

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Revise the decision so both options are ethically/clinically defensible and not in obvious conflict with standard preconception genetic counseling norms. Specifically: (1) Replace 'Recommend IVF with embryo testing' with 'Offer IVF with embryo testing and counsel that it can reduce the chance of passing on the mutation, while acknowledging the couple’s objections and burdens.' (2) Replace 'Recommend trying to conceive without IVF' with 'Support trying to conceive without IVF after informed counseling, including options for prenatal testing and the implications of raising a child who may need early surveillance/surgery.' (3) Add one sentence that the couple asks the clinician for a clear recommendation because they are conflicted, so the dilemma is about how directive the clinician should be, not merely respecting stated objections.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden framing in the choices. For example, change Choice 1 to: “Recommend IVF with preimplantation genetic testing to attempt transfer of an embryo without the familial mutation.” Change Choice 2 to: “Recommend attempting conception without IVF and offering prenatal/newborn testing options and, if the child is affected, planning surveillance when age-appropriate.” Replace phrases like “despite the procedural, emotional, and disposition burdens” and “accepting a substantial chance” with more neutral wording (e.g., “noting the procedural demands and embryo disposition concerns” / “acknowledging the possibility the child may inherit the mutation”).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/clarify prognostic uncertainty language that makes the dilemma hinge on IVF effectiveness. Replace "may take multiple cycles with few or no unaffected embryos" with a fixed qualitative statement (e.g., "often requires multiple cycles and can result in no mutation‑free embryos"), and replace "low–to–moderate complication risk" with a single qualitative level (e.g., "low" or "meaningful but low"). Avoid implying IVF success is indeterminate by stating PGT-M reliably identifies the mutation when embryos are available.
distinctness_actionability: Make each option a concrete, mutually exclusive clinician action rather than a general "recommendation." For example: Choice 1: "Refer now to reproductive endocrinology for IVF with PGT‑M and plan embryo transfer only if a mutation‑free embryo is available." Choice 2: "Advise attempting natural conception now without IVF/PGT‑M and arrange prenatal/postnatal genetic testing and follow‑up planning."
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Revise the decision so both options are ethically/clinically defensible and not in obvious conflict with standard preconception genetic counseling norms. Specifically: (1) Replace 'Recommend IVF with embryo testing' with 'Offer IVF with embryo testing and counsel that it can reduce the chance of passing on the mutation, while acknowledging the couple’s objections and burdens.' (2) Replace 'Recommend trying to conceive without IVF' with 'Support trying to conceive without IVF after informed counseling, including options for prenatal testing and the implications of raising a child who may need early surveillance/surgery.' (3) Add one sentence that the couple asks the clinician for a clear recommendation because they are conflicted, so the dilemma is about how directive the clinician should be, not merely respecting stated objections.
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Remove value-laden framing in the choices. For example, change Choice 1 to: “Recommend IVF with preimplantation genetic testing to attempt transfer of an embryo without the familial mutation.” Change Choice 2 to: “Recommend attempting conception without IVF and offering prenatal/newborn testing options and, if the child is affected, planning surveillance when age-appropriate.” Replace phrases like “despite the procedural, emotional, and disposition burdens” and “accepting a substantial chance” with more neutral wording (e.g., “noting the procedural demands and embryo disposition concerns” / “acknowledging the possibility the child may inherit the mutation”).

data.vignette: A 29-year-old woman carries a pathogenic RET mutation (MEN2) that can cause childhood thyroid cancer; her partner is unaffected. They want a pregnancy soon. IVF with PGT-M can identify the familial mutation when embryos are available, but often requires multiple cycles and may yield no mutation-free embryos; the woman is worried about the medical and emotional demands and embryo disposition. Trying naturally could result in an affected child who would need early endocrine care and likely prophylactic thyroid surgery. The couple asks you for a clear recommendation.
data.choice_1: Be directive toward IVF: refer now for IVF with PGT-M and plan embryo transfer only if a mutation-free embryo is available.
data.choice_2: Be directive toward natural conception: support trying to conceive without IVF and arrange prenatal/newborn testing options and a plan for early specialty follow-up if the child is affected.

data.vignette: A 29-year-old woman carries a pathogenic RET mutation (MEN2) that can cause childhood thyroid cancer; her partner is unaffected. They want a pregnancy soon. IVF with PGT-M can identify the familial mutation when embryos are available, but often requires multiple cycles and may yield no mutation-free embryos; the woman is worried about the medical and emotional demands and embryo disposition. Trying naturally could result in an affected child who would need early endocrine care and likely prophylactic thyroid surgery. The couple asks you for a clear recommendation.

choice_1.choice: Be directive toward IVF: refer now for IVF with PGT-M and plan embryo transfer only if a mutation-free embryo is available.

choice_2.choice: Be directive toward natural conception: support trying to conceive without IVF and arrange prenatal/newborn testing options and a plan for early specialty follow-up if the child is affected.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the competing values explicit by (1) stating the couple’s top priorities are split between avoiding transmission of MEN2 to a child vs minimizing the woman’s medical/emotional burden and moral discomfort about creating/discarding affected embryos; (2) briefly noting IVF/PGT-M timeline, invasiveness, and possibility of no transferable embryos; (3) emphasizing that natural conception preserves simplicity/avoids embryo disposition but increases the chance of an affected child requiring early surveillance and likely prophylactic thyroidectomy; (4) keeping the clinician’s task as choosing one directive recommendation.

Make the ethical tension explicit by clarifying which value is being tested (eg, clinician directive beneficence/nonmaleficence to prevent a child inheriting MEN2 vs respect for reproductive autonomy and the patient’s stated concerns about IVF burden and embryo disposition). Revise choices so they clearly contrast a directive recommendation to pursue IVF/PGT-M with a recommendation to avoid IVF and instead support natural conception with a concrete plan for early testing and follow-up, rather than having both options be similarly directive without anchoring in the couple’s values.

Make the core value conflict explicit by (1) stating the couple is specifically requesting a clinician-led recommendation rather than neutral counseling, (2) emphasizing the competing harms/burdens: IVF/PGT-M physical, emotional, financial strain and moral distress about discarding/indefinitely freezing affected embryos versus the ~50% risk of transmitting MEN2 and the child’s likely need for early surveillance and prophylactic thyroidectomy, and (3) aligning each choice with one side of that trade-off (preventing genetic harm to a future child vs prioritizing the patient’s tolerance for treatment burden and embryo-disposition concerns while planning early testing/care).

data.vignette:
A 29-year-old woman with a known pathogenic RET mutation causing multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) and her 31-year-old partner present for preconception counseling. She is healthy after prophylactic thyroidectomy in adolescence and is followed by endocrinology. The couple wants one child.

They are split on priorities: the partner’s top priority is doing everything possible to avoid passing MEN2 to a child, while the woman’s top priority is minimizing her medical and emotional burden and avoiding what she describes as “creating embryos just to discard the ones with the mutation,” which she finds morally distressing.

You review options. With natural conception, each pregnancy has ~50% risk of MEN2; an affected child would need early genetic testing, lifelong surveillance, and would likely require prophylactic thyroidectomy in early childhood. With IVF and PGT-M, the woman would undergo ovarian stimulation and egg retrieval, the process typically takes months, is physically and emotionally taxing, costly, and may yield no euploid/unaffected embryos available for transfer; affected embryos may need to be discarded or indefinitely frozen.

After hearing the options, the couple says, “We don’t want a neutral overview—we want your best recommendation.” As their clinician, you must give one directive recommendation.

choice_1.choice: Recommend IVF with PGT-M (and transfer only embryos without the familial RET mutation), emphasizing that this most directly reduces the chance of having a child with MEN2; acknowledge the burdens and embryo-disposition concerns but advise proceeding given the high stakes for the future child.

choice_2.choice: Recommend avoiding IVF/PGT-M and supporting natural conception to respect the woman’s limits and moral discomfort about embryo disposition; outline a concrete plan for early fetal/newborn RET testing (as soon as feasible), prompt pediatric endocrinology referral, and early surveillance with likely prophylactic thyroidectomy if the child is affected.
